taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges
cwe.description: The product attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to check whether privileges were dropped successfully
Ensure that privilege relinquishment is successful

cwe.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Privileges
cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to perform an operation, leading to resultant weaknesses.

cwe.name: Incorrect Default Permissions
cwe.description: During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Create files with appropriate access permissions
Create files with appropriate access permission
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Insecure Inherited Permissions
cwe.description: A product defines a set of insecure permissions that are inherited by objects that are created by the program.

cwe.name: Insecure Preserved Inherited Permissions
cwe.description: A product inherits a set of insecure permissions for an object, e.g. when copying from an archive file, without user awareness or involvement.

cwe.name: Incorrect Execution-Assigned Permissions
cwe.description: While it is executing, the product sets the permissions of an object in a way that violates the intended permissions that have been specified by the user.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Create files with appropriate access permissions
Create files with appropriate access permission
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Permissions or Privileges
cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to access resources or functionality as specified by their permissions. This may cause it to follow unexpected code paths that may leave the product in an invalid state.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Fails poorly due to insufficient permissions

cwe.name: Improper Preservation of Permissions
cwe.description: The product does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.

cwe.name: Improper Ownership Management
cwe.description: The product assigns the wrong ownership, or does not properly verify the ownership, of an object or resource.

cwe.name: Unverified Ownership
cwe.description: The product does not properly verify that a critical resource is owned by the proper entity.

cwe.name: Improper Access Control
cwe.description: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

cwe.name: Improper Authorization
cwe.description: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

cwe.name: Incorrect User Management
cwe.description: The product does not properly manage a user within its environment.

cwe.name: Improper Authentication
cwe.description: When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

cwe.name: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel
cwe.description: The product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.

cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Alternate Name
cwe.description: The product performs authentication based on the name of a resource being accessed, or the name of the actor performing the access, but it does not properly check all possible names for that resource or actor.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)
SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java

cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Spoofing
cwe.description: This attack-focused weakness is caused by incorrectly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks.

cwe.name: Reliance on IP Address for Authentication
cwe.description: The product uses an IP address for authentication.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Trusting Self-reported DNS Name
cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.

cwe.name: Using Referer Field for Authentication
cwe.description: The referer field in HTTP requests can be easily modified and, as such, is not a valid means of message integrity checking.

cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay
cwe.description: A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).

cwe.name: Improper Certificate Validation
cwe.description: The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.

cwe.name: Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust
cwe.description: The product does not follow, or incorrectly follows, the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate, resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to follow chain of trust in certificate validation

cwe.name: Improper Validation of Certificate with Host Mismatch
cwe.description: The product communicates with a host that provides a certificate, but the product does not properly ensure that the certificate is actually associated with that host.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to validate host-specific certificate data

cwe.name: Improper Validation of Certificate Expiration
cwe.description: A certificate expiration is not validated or is incorrectly validated, so trust may be assigned to certificates that have been abandoned due to age.

cwe.name: Improper Check for Certificate Revocation
cwe.description: The product does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate, which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to check for certificate revocation

cwe.name: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint
cwe.description: The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not rely on the default automatic signature verification provided by URLClassLoader and java.util.jar
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Reflection Attack in an Authentication Protocol
cwe.description: Simple authentication protocols are subject to reflection attacks if a malicious user can use the target machine to impersonate a trusted user.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Reflection attack in an auth protocol

cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Assumed-Immutable Data
cwe.description: The authentication scheme or implementation uses key data elements that are assumed to be immutable, but can be controlled or modified by the attacker.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not base security checks on untrusted sources
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Incorrect Implementation of Authentication Algorithm
cwe.description: The requirements for the product dictate the use of an established authentication algorithm, but the implementation of the algorithm is incorrect.

cwe.name: Missing Critical Step in Authentication
cwe.description: The product implements an authentication technique, but it skips a step that weakens the technique.

cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Primary Weakness
cwe.description: The authentication algorithm is sound, but the implemented mechanism can be bypassed as the result of a separate weakness that is primary to the authentication error.

cwe.name: Missing Authentication for Critical Function
cwe.description: The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts
cwe.description: The product does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within a short time frame.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Multiple Failed Authentication Attempts not Prevented

cwe.name: Use of Single-factor Authentication
cwe.description: The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme.

cwe.name: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication
cwe.description: The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings, each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

cwe.name: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
cwe.description: The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use SSLSocket rather than Socket for secure data exchange
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage in a File or on Disk
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a file, or on disk.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Plaintext Storage in File or on Disk

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage in the Registry
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in the registry.

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a cookie.

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Memory
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in memory.

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in GUI
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within the GUI.

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Executable
cwe.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in an executable.

cwe.name: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
cwe.description: The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not rely on the default automatic signature verification provided by URLClassLoader and java.util.jar
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Sign then seal sensitive objects before sending them outside a trust boundary
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key
cwe.description: The product uses a hard-coded, unchangeable cryptographic key.

cwe.name: Key Exchange without Entity Authentication
cwe.description: The product performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor.

cwe.name: Reusing a Nonce, Key Pair in Encryption
cwe.description: Nonces should be used for the present occasion and only once.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Reusing a nonce, key pair in encryption

cwe.name: Use of a Key Past its Expiration Date
cwe.description: The product uses a cryptographic key or password past its expiration date, which diminishes its safety significantly by increasing the timing window for cracking attacks against that key.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Using a key past its expiration date

cwe.name: Missing Cryptographic Step
cwe.description: The product does not implement a required step in a cryptographic algorithm, resulting in weaker encryption than advertised by the algorithm.

cwe.name: Inadequate Encryption Strength
cwe.description: The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required.

cwe.name: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
cwe.description: The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Using a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm
Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Use of Weak Hash
cwe.description: The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack), find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack), or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack).

cwe.name: Generation of Predictable IV with CBC Mode
cwe.description: The product generates and uses a predictable initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode, which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Not using a random IV with CBC mode

cwe.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
cwe.description: The product uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Avoid race conditions when using library functions
Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Insufficient Entropy
cwe.description: The product uses an algorithm or scheme that produces insufficient entropy, leaving patterns or clusters of values that are more likely to occur than others.

cwe.name: Insufficient Entropy in PRNG
cwe.description: The lack of entropy available for, or used by, a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) can be a stability and security threat.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
cwe.description: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Small Space of Random Values
cwe.description: The number of possible random values is smaller than needed by the product, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

cwe.name: Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
cwe.description: The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) but does not correctly manage seeds.

cwe.name: Same Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
cwe.description: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses the same seed each time the product is initialized.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Predictable Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
cwe.description: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) is initialized from a predictable seed, such as the process ID or system time.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Use of Cryptographically Weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
cwe.description: The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) in a security context, but the PRNG's algorithm is not cryptographically strong.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers

cwe.name: Small Seed Space in PRNG
cwe.description: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses a relatively small seed space, which makes it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

cwe.name: Generation of Predictable Numbers or Identifiers
cwe.description: The product uses a scheme that generates numbers or identifiers that are more predictable than required.

cwe.name: Predictable from Observable State
cwe.description: A number or object is predictable based on observations that the attacker can make about the state of the system or network, such as time, process ID, etc.

cwe.name: Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values
cwe.description: An exact value or random number can be precisely predicted by observing previous values.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values

cwe.name: Predictable Value Range from Previous Values
cwe.description: The product's random number generator produces a series of values which, when observed, can be used to infer a relatively small range of possibilities for the next value that could be generated.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Predictable Value Range from Previous Values

cwe.name: Use of Invariant Value in Dynamically Changing Context
cwe.description: The product uses a constant value, name, or reference, but this value can (or should) vary across different environments.

cwe.name: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity
cwe.description: The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

cwe.name: Origin Validation Error
cwe.description: The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

cwe.name: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature
cwe.description: The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not rely on the default automatic signature verification provided by URLClassLoader and java.util.jar
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Use of Less Trusted Source
cwe.description: The product has two different sources of the same data or information, but it uses the source that has less support for verification, is less trusted, or is less resistant to attack.

cwe.name: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data
cwe.description: The product, when processing trusted data, accepts any untrusted data that is also included with the trusted data, treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Untrusted Data Appended with Trusted Data
Place all security-sensitive code in a single JAR and sign and seal it
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Reliance on Reverse DNS Resolution for a Security-Critical Action
cwe.description: The product performs reverse DNS resolution on an IP address to obtain the hostname and make a security decision, but it does not properly ensure that the IP address is truly associated with the hostname.

cwe.name: Insufficient Type Distinction
cwe.description: The product does not properly distinguish between different types of elements in a way that leads to insecure behavior.

cwe.name: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
cwe.description: The web application does not, or cannot, sufficiently verify whether a request was intentionally provided by the user who sent the request, which could have originated from an unauthorized actor.

cwe.name: Missing Support for Integrity Check
cwe.description: The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to add integrity check value

cwe.name: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value
cwe.description: The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to check integrity check value

cwe.name: Product UI does not Warn User of Unsafe Actions
cwe.description: The product's user interface does not warn the user before undertaking an unsafe action on behalf of that user. This makes it easier for attackers to trick users into inflicting damage to their system.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Product UI does not warn user of unsafe actions

cwe.name: Insufficient UI Warning of Dangerous Operations
cwe.description: The user interface provides a warning to a user regarding dangerous or sensitive operations, but the warning is not noticeable enough to warrant attention.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Insufficient UI warning of dangerous operations

cwe.name: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard
cwe.description: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm, protocol, or technique.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard

cwe.name: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
cwe.description: The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not log sensitive information outside a trust boundary
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Trust of System Event Data
cwe.description: Security based on event locations are insecure and can be spoofed.

cwe.name: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')
cwe.description: The product contains a concurrent code sequence that requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence operating concurrently.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not assume that a group of calls to independently atomic methods is atomic
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Race Condition Enabling Link Following
cwe.description: The product checks the status of a file or directory before accessing it, which produces a race condition in which the file can be replaced with a link before the access is performed, causing the product to access the wrong file.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Avoid race conditions while checking for the existence of a symbolic link

cwe.name: Signal Handler Race Condition
cwe.description: The product uses a signal handler that introduces a race condition.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Race Condition in Switch
cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated. There are no documented cases in which a switch's control expression is evaluated more than once.

cwe.name: Race Condition within a Thread
cwe.description: If two threads of execution use a resource simultaneously, there exists the possibility that resources may be used while invalid, in turn making the state of execution undefined.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Prevent data races when accessing bit-fields from multiple threads
Do not refer to an atomic variable twice in an expression
Do not allow data races in multithreaded code
Ensure that compound operations on shared variables are atomic
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not assume that a group of calls to independently atomic methods is atomic
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition
cwe.description: The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource, but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check. This can cause the product to perform invalid actions when the resource is in an unexpected state.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Time of check, time of use race condition
Be careful using functions that use file names for identification

cwe.name: Context Switching Race Condition
cwe.description: A product performs a series of non-atomic actions to switch between contexts that cross privilege or other security boundaries, but a race condition allows an attacker to modify or misrepresent the product's behavior during the switch.

cwe.name: Divide By Zero
cwe.description: The product divides a value by zero.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Detect and handle floating point errors
Ensure that division and remainder operations do not result in divide-by-zero errors
Ensure that division and modulo operations do not result in divide-by-zero errors
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Missing Check for Certificate Revocation after Initial Check
cwe.description: The product does not check the revocation status of a certificate after its initial revocation check, which can cause the product to perform privileged actions even after the certificate is revoked at a later time.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Race condition in checking for certificate revocation

cwe.name: Incomplete Internal State Distinction
cwe.description: The product does not properly determine which state it is in, causing it to assume it is in state X when in fact it is in state Y, causing it to perform incorrect operations in a security-relevant manner.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: State Synchronization Error
cwe.description: This entry was deprecated because it overlapped the same concepts as race condition (CWE-362) and Improper Synchronization (CWE-662).

cwe.name: Passing Mutable Objects to an Untrusted Method
cwe.description: The product sends non-cloned mutable data as an argument to a method or function.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Passing mutable objects to an untrusted method
Provide mutable classes with copy functionality to safely allow passing instances to untrusted code
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Returning a Mutable Object to an Untrusted Caller
cwe.description: Sending non-cloned mutable data as a return value may result in that data being altered or deleted by the calling function.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Provide mutable classes with copy functionality to safely allow passing instances to untrusted code
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Defensively copy private mutable class members before returning their references
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not modify $_ in list or sorting functions

cwe.name: Insecure Temporary File
cwe.description: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Avoid race conditions when using library functions
Do not operate on files in shared directories
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Creation of Temporary File With Insecure Permissions
cwe.description: Opening temporary files without appropriate measures or controls can leave the file, its contents and any function that it impacts vulnerable to attack.

cwe.name: Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions
cwe.description: The product creates a temporary file in a directory whose permissions allow unintended actors to determine the file's existence or otherwise access that file.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure that file operations are performed in a secure directory

cwe.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
cwe.description: A J2EE application uses System.exit(), which also shuts down its container.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not allow untrusted code to terminate the JVM
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
cwe.description: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.

cwe.name: Session Fixation
cwe.description: Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

cwe.name: Covert Timing Channel
cwe.description: Covert timing channels convey information by modulating some aspect of system behavior over time, so that the program receiving the information can observe system behavior and infer protected information.

cwe.name: Symbolic Name not Mapping to Correct Object
cwe.description: A constant symbolic reference to an object is used, even though the reference can resolve to a different object over time.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Symbolic name not mapping to correct object

cwe.name: Detection of Error Condition Without Action
cwe.description: The product detects a specific error, but takes no actions to handle the error.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not suppress or ignore checked exceptions
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Unchecked Error Condition
cwe.description: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES AND CONSIDER CWE-252, CWE-248, OR CWE-1069.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

Detect and handle standard library errors
Detect errors when converting a string to a number
Prevent or detect domain and range errors in math functions
Detect and handle POSIX library errors

cwe.name: Missing Report of Error Condition
cwe.description: The product encounters an error but does not provide a status code or return value to indicate that an error has occurred.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure that tasks executing in a thread pool do not fail silently
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Return of Wrong Status Code
cwe.description: A function or operation returns an incorrect return value or status code that does not indicate the true result of execution, causing the product to modify its behavior based on the incorrect result.

cwe.name: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value
cwe.description: The product does not properly check when a function or operation returns a value that is legitimate for the function, but is not expected by the product.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value

cwe.name: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
cwe.description: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not catch NullPointerException or any of its ancestors
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
cwe.description: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

cwe.name: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
cwe.description: The product throws or raises an overly broad exceptions that can hide important details and produce inappropriate responses to certain conditions.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not throw RuntimeException, Exception, or Throwable
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
cwe.description: The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Resource exhaustion (file descriptor, disk space, sockets, ...)
Avoid memory and resource leaks during serialization
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)
The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
cwe.description: The product does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used, making the memory unavailable for reallocation and reuse.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Free dynamically allocated memory when no longer needed

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')
cwe.description: The product makes resources available to untrusted parties when those resources are only intended to be accessed by the product.

cwe.name: Exposure of File Descriptor to Unintended Control Sphere ('File Descriptor Leak')
cwe.description: A process does not close sensitive file descriptors before invoking a child process, which allows the child to perform unauthorized I/O operations using those descriptors.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure files are properly closed when they are no longer needed

cwe.name: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release
cwe.description: The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Close files when they are no longer needed
Free dynamically allocated memory when no longer needed
Release resources when they are no longer needed
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Asymmetric Resource Consumption (Amplification)
cwe.description: The product does not properly control situations in which an adversary can cause the product to consume or produce excessive resources without requiring the adversary to invest equivalent work or otherwise prove authorization, i.e., the adversary's influence is "asymmetric."

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use thread pools to enable graceful degradation of service during traffic bursts
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Release resources when they are no longer needed
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Insufficient Control of Network Message Volume (Network Amplification)
cwe.description: The product does not sufficiently monitor or control transmitted network traffic volume, so that an actor can cause the product to transmit more traffic than should be allowed for that actor.

cwe.name: Inefficient Algorithmic Complexity
cwe.description: An algorithm in a product has an inefficient worst-case computational complexity that may be detrimental to system performance and can be triggered by an attacker, typically using crafted manipulations that ensure that the worst case is being reached.

cwe.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Amplification
cwe.description: The product allows an entity to perform a legitimate but expensive operation before authentication or authorization has taken place.

cwe.name: Improper Handling of Highly Compressed Data (Data Amplification)
cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Limit the size of files passed to ZipInputStream
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Insufficient Resource Pool
cwe.description: The product's resource pool is not large enough to handle peak demand, which allows an attacker to prevent others from accessing the resource by using a (relatively) large number of requests for resources.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use thread pools to enable graceful degradation of service during traffic bursts
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Unrestricted Externally Accessible Lock
cwe.description: The product properly checks for the existence of a lock, but the lock can be externally controlled or influenced by an actor that is outside of the intended sphere of control.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use private final lock objects to synchronize classes that may interact with untrusted code
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Avoid deadlock by requesting and releasing locks in the same order
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Improper Resource Locking
cwe.description: The product does not lock or does not correctly lock a resource when the product must have exclusive access to the resource.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure visibility when accessing shared primitive variables
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure that compound operations on shared variables are atomic
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use private final lock objects to synchronize classes that may interact with untrusted code
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Missing Lock Check
cwe.description: A product does not check to see if a lock is present before performing sensitive operations on a resource.

cwe.name: Double Free
cwe.description: The product calls free() twice on the same memory address.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Allocate and free memory in the same module, at the same level of abstraction
Store a new value in pointers immediately after free()
Free dynamically allocated memory exactly once

cwe.name: Use After Free
cwe.description: The product reuses or references memory after it has been freed. At some point afterward, the memory may be allocated again and saved in another pointer, while the original pointer references a location somewhere within the new allocation. Any operations using the original pointer are no longer valid because the memory "belongs" to the code that operates on the new pointer.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Allocate and free memory in the same module, at the same level of abstraction
Store a new value in pointers immediately after free()

cwe.name: Unprotected Primary Channel
cwe.description: The product uses a primary channel for administration or restricted functionality, but it does not properly protect the channel.

cwe.name: Unprotected Alternate Channel
cwe.description: The product protects a primary channel, but it does not use the same level of protection for an alternate channel.

cwe.name: Race Condition During Access to Alternate Channel
cwe.description: The product opens an alternate channel to communicate with an authorized user, but the channel is accessible to other actors.

cwe.name: Unprotected Windows Messaging Channel ('Shatter')
cwe.description: The product does not properly verify the source of a message in the Windows Messaging System while running at elevated privileges, creating an alternate channel through which an attacker can directly send a message to the product.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Proxied Trusted Channel
cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-441. All content has been transferred to CWE-441.

cwe.name: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
cwe.description: The product does not sufficiently protect all possible paths that a user can take to access restricted functionality or resources.

cwe.name: Direct Request ('Forced Browsing')
cwe.description: The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs, scripts, or files.

cwe.name: Untrusted Search Path
cwe.description: The product searches for critical resources using an externally-supplied search path that can point to resources that are not under the product's direct control.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Sanitize the environment when invoking external programs

cwe.name: Uncontrolled Search Path Element
cwe.description: The product uses a fixed or controlled search path to find resources, but one or more locations in that path can be under the control of unintended actors.

cwe.name: Unquoted Search Path or Element
cwe.description: The product uses a search path that contains an unquoted element, in which the element contains whitespace or other separators. This can cause the product to access resources in a parent path.

cwe.name: Deployment of Wrong Handler
cwe.description: The wrong "handler" is assigned to process an object.

cwe.name: Missing Handler
cwe.description: A handler is not available or implemented.

cwe.name: Dangerous Signal Handler not Disabled During Sensitive Operations
cwe.description: The product uses a signal handler that shares state with other signal handlers, but it does not properly mask or prevent those signal handlers from being invoked while the original signal handler is still running.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Mask signals handled by noninterruptible signal handlers
Dangerous handler not cleared/disabled during sensitive operations

cwe.name: Unparsed Raw Web Content Delivery
cwe.description: The product stores raw content or supporting code under the web document root with an extension that is not specifically handled by the server.

cwe.name: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
cwe.description: The product allows the upload or transfer of dangerous file types that are automatically processed within its environment.

cwe.name: Improper Interaction Between Multiple Correctly-Behaving Entities
cwe.description: An interaction error occurs when two entities have correct behavior when running independently of each other, but when they are integrated as components in a larger system or process, they introduce incorrect behaviors that may cause resultant weaknesses.

cwe.name: Interpretation Conflict
cwe.description: Product A handles inputs or steps differently than Product B, which causes A to perform incorrect actions based on its perception of B's state.

cwe.name: Incomplete Model of Endpoint Features
cwe.description: A product acts as an intermediary or monitor between two or more endpoints, but it does not have a complete model of an endpoint's features, behaviors, or state, potentially causing the product to perform incorrect actions based on this incomplete model.

cwe.name: Behavioral Change in New Version or Environment
cwe.description: A's behavior or functionality changes with a new version of A, or a new environment, which is not known (or manageable) by B.

cwe.name: Expected Behavior Violation
cwe.description: A feature, API, or function does not perform according to its specification.

cwe.name: Unintended Proxy or Intermediary ('Confused Deputy')
cwe.description: The product receives a request, message, or directive from an upstream component, but the product does not sufficiently preserve the original source of the request before forwarding the request to an external actor that is outside of the product's control sphere. This causes the product to appear to be the source of the request, leading it to act as a proxy or other intermediary between the upstream component and the external actor.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: HTTP response splitting
cwe.description: This weakness can be found at CWE-113.

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')
cwe.description: The product acts as an intermediary HTTP agent (such as a proxy or firewall) in the data flow between two entities such as a client and server, but it does not interpret malformed HTTP requests or responses in ways that are consistent with how the messages will be processed by those entities that are at the ultimate destination.

cwe.name: UI Discrepancy for Security Feature
cwe.description: The user interface does not correctly enable or configure a security feature, but the interface provides feedback that causes the user to believe that the feature is in a secure state.

cwe.name: Unimplemented or Unsupported Feature in UI
cwe.description: A UI function for a security feature appears to be supported and gives feedback to the user that suggests that it is supported, but the underlying functionality is not implemented.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Unimplemented or unsupported feature in UI

cwe.name: Obsolete Feature in UI
cwe.description: A UI function is obsolete and the product does not warn the user.

cwe.name: The UI Performs the Wrong Action
cwe.description: The UI performs the wrong action with respect to the user's request.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: The UI performs the wrong action

cwe.name: Multiple Interpretations of UI Input
cwe.description: The UI has multiple interpretations of user input but does not prompt the user when it selects the less secure interpretation.

cwe.name: User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information
cwe.description: The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user, allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks.

cwe.name: Insecure Default Variable Initialization
cwe.description: The product, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.

cwe.name: External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores
cwe.description: The product initializes critical internal variables or data stores using inputs that can be modified by untrusted actors.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: External initialization of trusted variables or values

cwe.name: Non-exit on Failed Initialization
cwe.description: The product does not exit or otherwise modify its operation when security-relevant errors occur during initialization, such as when a configuration file has a format error or a hardware security module (HSM) cannot be activated, which can cause the product to execute in a less secure fashion than intended by the administrator.

cwe.name: Missing Initialization of a Variable
cwe.description: The product does not initialize critical variables, which causes the execution environment to use unexpected values.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Set errno to zero before calling a library function known to set errno,  and check errno only after the function returns a value indicating failure

cwe.name: Use of Uninitialized Variable
cwe.description: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Incorrect Initialization
cwe.description: This weakness has been deprecated because its name and description did not match. The description duplicated CWE-454, while the name suggested a more abstract initialization problem. Please refer to CWE-665 for the more abstract problem.

cwe.name: Incomplete Cleanup
cwe.description: The product does not properly "clean up" and remove temporary or supporting resources after they have been used.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Close files when they are no longer needed
Free dynamically allocated memory when no longer needed
Release resources when they are no longer needed
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not operate on files in shared directories
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Improper Cleanup on Thrown Exception
cwe.description: The product does not clean up its state or incorrectly cleans up its state when an exception is thrown, leading to unexpected state or control flow.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Restore prior object state on method failure
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not let checked exceptions escape from a finally block
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not suppress or ignore exceptions

cwe.name: Duplicate Key in Associative List (Alist)
cwe.description: Duplicate keys in associative lists can lead to non-unique keys being mistaken for an error.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Beware of multiple environment variables with the same effective name

cwe.name: Deletion of Data Structure Sentinel
cwe.description: The accidental deletion of a data-structure sentinel can cause serious programming logic problems.

cwe.name: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel
cwe.description: The accidental addition of a data-structure sentinel can cause serious programming logic problems.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not inadvertently truncate a null-terminated byte string
Do not assume that strtok() leaves the parse string unchanged

cwe.name: Return of Pointer Value Outside of Expected Range
cwe.description: A function can return a pointer to memory that is outside of the buffer that the pointer is expected to reference.

cwe.name: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type
cwe.description: The code calls sizeof() on a pointer type, which can be an incorrect calculation if the programmer intended to determine the size of the data that is being pointed to.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use of sizeof() on a pointer type
Do not apply the sizeof operator to a pointer when taking the size of an array
Allocate sufficient memory for an object

cwe.name: Incorrect Pointer Scaling
cwe.description: In C and C++, one may often accidentally refer to the wrong memory due to the semantics of when math operations are implicitly scaled.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not add or subtract a scaled integer to a pointer
Ensure pointer arithmetic is used correctly

cwe.name: Use of Pointer Subtraction to Determine Size
cwe.description: The product subtracts one pointer from another in order to determine size, but this calculation can be incorrect if the pointers do not exist in the same memory chunk.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not subtract or compare two pointers that do not refer to the same array

cwe.name: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')
cwe.description: The product uses external input with reflection to select which classes or code to use, but it does not sufficiently prevent the input from selecting improper classes or code.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use reflection to increase accessibility of classes, methods, or fields
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID)
cwe.description: The product does not properly protect an assumed-immutable element from being modified by an attacker.

cwe.name: External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter
cwe.description: The web application does not sufficiently verify inputs that are assumed to be immutable but are actually externally controllable, such as hidden form fields.

cwe.name: PHP External Variable Modification
cwe.description: A PHP application does not properly protect against the modification of variables from external sources, such as query parameters or cookies. This can expose the application to numerous weaknesses that would not exist otherwise.

cwe.name: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
cwe.description: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions.

cwe.name: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
cwe.description: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

cwe.name: NULL Pointer Dereference
cwe.description: The product dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid but is NULL.

cwe.name: Use of Obsolete Function
cwe.description: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use deprecated or obsolete functions or modules

cwe.name: Missing Default Case in Multiple Condition Expression
cwe.description: The code does not have a default case in an expression with multiple conditions, such as a switch statement.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to account for default case in switch

cwe.name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function
cwe.description: The product defines a signal handler that calls a non-reentrant function.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Unsafe function call from a signal handler
Call only asynchronous-safe functions within signal handlers
Do not call signal() from within interruptible signal handlers

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Use of Incorrect Operator
cwe.description: The product accidentally uses the wrong operator, which changes the logic in security-relevant ways.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not perform assignments in selection statements
Do not use a bitwise operator with a Boolean-like operand

cwe.name: Assigning instead of Comparing
cwe.description: The code uses an operator for assignment when the intention was to perform a comparison.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not perform assignments in selection statements

cwe.name: Comparing instead of Assigning
cwe.description: The code uses an operator for comparison when the intention was to perform an assignment.

cwe.name: Incorrect Block Delimitation
cwe.description: The code does not explicitly delimit a block that is intended to contain 2 or more statements, creating a logic error.

cwe.name: Omitted Break Statement in Switch
cwe.description: The product omits a break statement within a switch or similar construct, causing code associated with multiple conditions to execute. This can cause problems when the programmer only intended to execute code associated with one condition.

cwe.name: Comparison of Classes by Name
cwe.description: The product compares classes by name, which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Compare classes and not class names
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Reliance on Package-level Scope
cwe.description: Java packages are not inherently closed; therefore, relying on them for code security is not a good practice.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not increase the accessibility of overridden or hidden methods
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session
cwe.description: The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions, causing data to be provided to, or used by, the wrong session.

cwe.name: Active Debug Code
cwe.description: The product is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active, which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information.

cwe.name: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')
cwe.description: A class has a cloneable() method that is not declared final, which allows an object to be created without calling the constructor. This can cause the object to be in an unexpected state.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Sensitive classes must not let themselves be copied
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data
cwe.description: Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Mobile Code: Use of Inner Class
Publicizing of private data when using inner classes
Do not expose private members of an outer class from within a nested class
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier
cwe.description: The product has a critical public variable that is not final, which allows the variable to be modified to contain unexpected values.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Failure to provide confidentiality for stored data
Do not use public static nonfinal variables
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check
cwe.description: The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not rely on the default automatic signature verification provided by URLClassLoader and java.util.jar
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Private Data Structure Returned From A Public Method
cwe.description: The product has a method that is declared public, but returns a reference to a private data structure, which could then be modified in unexpected ways.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Private Array-Typed Field Returned From A Public Method

cwe.name: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field
cwe.description: Assigning public data to a private array is equivalent to giving public access to the array.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field

cwe.name: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
cwe.description: The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not allow exceptions to expose sensitive information
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Cloneable Class Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class is cloneable. The data can then be accessed by cloning the class.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Sensitive classes must not let themselves be copied
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Serializable Class Containing Sensitive Data
cwe.description: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class does not explicitly deny serialization. The data can be accessed by serializing the class through another class.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not serialize unencrypted, sensitive data
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not serialize instances of inner classes
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Public Static Field Not Marked Final
cwe.description: An object contains a public static field that is not marked final, which might allow it to be modified in unexpected ways.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use public static nonfinal variables
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Trust Boundary Violation
cwe.description: The product mixes trusted and untrusted data in the same data structure or structured message.

cwe.name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
cwe.description: The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently ensuring that the resulting data will be valid.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not deviate from the proper signatures of serialization methods
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not serialize unencrypted, sensitive data
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Make defensive copies of private mutable components during deserialization
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use the default serialized form for implementation defined invariants
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Embedded Malicious Code
cwe.description: The product contains code that appears to be malicious in nature.

cwe.name: Trojan Horse
cwe.description: The product appears to contain benign or useful functionality, but it also contains code that is hidden from normal operation that violates the intended security policy of the user or the system administrator.

cwe.name: Non-Replicating Malicious Code
cwe.description: Non-replicating malicious code only resides on the target system or product that is attacked; it does not attempt to spread to other systems.

cwe.name: Replicating Malicious Code (Virus or Worm)
cwe.description: Replicating malicious code, including viruses and worms, will attempt to attack other systems once it has successfully compromised the target system or the product.

cwe.name: Trapdoor
cwe.description: A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input, allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism.

cwe.name: Logic/Time Bomb
cwe.description: The product contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the product (or its environment) when a certain time passes, or when a certain logical condition is met.

cwe.name: Spyware
cwe.description: The product collects personally identifiable information about a human user or the user's activities, but the product accesses this information using other resources besides itself, and it does not require that user's explicit approval or direct input into the product.

cwe.name: Covert Channel
cwe.description: A covert channel is a path that can be used to transfer information in a way not intended by the system's designers.

cwe.name: Covert Storage Channel
cwe.description: A covert storage channel transfers information through the setting of bits by one program and the reading of those bits by another. What distinguishes this case from that of ordinary operation is that the bits are used to convey encoded information.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Covert Timing Channel
cwe.description: This weakness can be found at CWE-385.

cwe.name: .NET Misconfiguration: Use of Impersonation
cwe.description: Allowing a .NET application to run at potentially escalated levels of access to the underlying operating and file systems can be dangerous and result in various forms of attacks.

cwe.name: Weak Password Requirements
cwe.description: The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts.

cwe.name: Insufficiently Protected Credentials
cwe.description: The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

cwe.name: Unprotected Transport of Credentials
cwe.description: Login pages do not use adequate measures to protect the user name and password while they are in transit from the client to the server.

cwe.name: Use of Cache Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: The code uses a cache that contains sensitive information, but the cache can be read by an actor outside of the intended control sphere.

cwe.name: Use of Web Browser Cache Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: The web application does not use an appropriate caching policy that specifies the extent to which each web page and associated form fields should be cached.

cwe.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in an Environment Variable
cwe.description: The product uses an environment variable to store unencrypted sensitive information.

cwe.name: Exposure of Version-Control Repository to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
cwe.description: The product stores a CVS, git, or other repository in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

cwe.name: Exposure of Core Dump File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
cwe.description: The product generates a core dump file in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure that sensitive data is not written out to disk

cwe.name: Exposure of Access Control List Files to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
cwe.description: The product stores access control list files in a directory or other container that is accessible to actors outside of the intended control sphere.

cwe.name: Exposure of Backup File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
cwe.description: A backup file is stored in a directory or archive that is made accessible to unauthorized actors.

cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Test Code
cwe.description: Accessible test applications can pose a variety of security risks. Since developers or administrators rarely consider that someone besides themselves would even know about the existence of these applications, it is common for them to contain sensitive information or functions.

cwe.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
cwe.description: The product writes sensitive information to a log file.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not log sensitive information outside a trust boundary
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Server Log Files
cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level. See CWE-532.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Debug Log Files
cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level. See CWE-532.

cwe.name: Exposure of Information Through Shell Error Message
cwe.description: A command shell error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code. In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause these errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

cwe.name: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in your web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.

cwe.name: Java Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause unhandled exception errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

cwe.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory
cwe.description: The product places sensitive information into files or directories that are accessible to actors who are allowed to have access to the files, but not to the sensitive information.

cwe.name: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information.

cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
cwe.description: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users.

cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File
cwe.description: If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Cleanup Log Files
cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level. See CWE-532.

cwe.name: Use of Singleton Pattern Without Synchronization in a Multithreaded Context
cwe.description: The product uses the singleton pattern when creating a resource within a multithreaded environment.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Prevent multiple instantiations of singleton objects
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism
cwe.description: The product does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code, which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Adopt and implement a consistent and comprehensive error-handling policy

cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Use of Dynamic Class Loading
cwe.description: This weakness has been deprecated because it partially overlaps CWE-470, it describes legitimate programmer behavior, and other portions will need to be integrated into other entries.

cwe.name: Suspicious Comment
cwe.description: The code contains comments that suggest the presence of bugs, incomplete functionality, or weaknesses.

cwe.name: Use of Hard-coded, Security-relevant Constants
cwe.description: The product uses hard-coded constants instead of symbolic names for security-critical values, which increases the likelihood of mistakes during code maintenance or security policy change.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Use meaningful symbolic constants to represent literal values in program logic

cwe.name: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing
cwe.description: The product inappropriately exposes a directory listing with an index of all the resources located inside of the directory.

cwe.name: Missing Password Field Masking
cwe.description: The product does not mask passwords during entry, increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords.

cwe.name: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.description: Certain conditions, such as network failure, will cause a server error message to be displayed.

cwe.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization
cwe.description: If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization, it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection.

cwe.name: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties
cwe.description: The product makes files or directories accessible to unauthorized actors, even though they should not be.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure that file operations are performed in a secure directory

cwe.name: Command Shell in Externally Accessible Directory
cwe.description: A possible shell file exists in /cgi-bin/ or other accessible directories. This is extremely dangerous and can be used by an attacker to execute commands on the web server.

cwe.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Not Using Input Validation Framework
cwe.description: The ASP.NET application does not use an input validation framework.

cwe.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Plaintext Password in Configuration File
cwe.description: The J2EE application stores a plaintext password in a configuration file.

cwe.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Use of Identity Impersonation
cwe.description: Configuring an ASP.NET application to run with impersonated credentials may give the application unnecessary privileges.

cwe.name: Use of getlogin() in Multithreaded Application
cwe.description: The product uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.

cwe.name: Use of umask() with chmod-style Argument
cwe.description: The product calls umask() with an incorrect argument that is specified as if it is an argument to chmod().

cwe.name: Dead Code
cwe.description: The product contains dead code, which can never be executed.

cwe.name: Return of Stack Variable Address
cwe.description: A function returns the address of a stack variable, which will cause unintended program behavior, typically in the form of a crash.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Declare objects with appropriate storage durations
Do not call putenv() with a pointer to an automatic variable as the argument

cwe.name: Assignment to Variable without Use
cwe.description: The variable's value is assigned but never used, making it a dead store.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Compile cleanly at high warning levels

cwe.name: SQL Injection: Hibernate
cwe.description: Using Hibernate to execute a dynamic SQL statement built with user-controlled input can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.

cwe.name: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking
cwe.description: The product relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations, but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user.

cwe.name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled SQL Primary Key
cwe.description: The product uses a database table that includes records that should not be accessible to an actor, but it executes a SQL statement with a primary key that can be controlled by that actor.

cwe.name: Unsynchronized Access to Shared Data in a Multithreaded Context
cwe.description: The product does not properly synchronize shared data, such as static variables across threads, which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure visibility when accessing shared primitive variables
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Ensure that compound operations on shared variables are atomic
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: finalize() Method Without super.finalize()
cwe.description: The product contains a finalize() method that does not call super.finalize().

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Expression is Always False
cwe.description: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to false.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Compile cleanly at high warning levels

cwe.name: Expression is Always True
cwe.description: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to true.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Compile cleanly at high warning levels

cwe.name: Call to Thread run() instead of start()
cwe.description: The product calls a thread's run() method instead of calling start(), which causes the code to run in the thread of the caller instead of the callee.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Improper Following of Specification by Caller
cwe.description: The product does not follow or incorrectly follows the specifications as required by the implementation language, environment, framework, protocol, or platform.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Follow the general contract when implementing the compareTo() method
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives
cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives.

cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of AWT Swing
cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using AWT/Swing.

cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Java I/O
cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the java.io package.

cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Sockets
cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets.

cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Class Loader
cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the class loader.

cwe.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-serializable Object Stored in Session
cwe.description: The product stores a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute, which can hurt reliability.

cwe.name: clone() Method Without super.clone()
cwe.description: The product contains a clone() method that does not call super.clone() to obtain the new object.

cwe.name: Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined
cwe.description: The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Classes that define an equals() method must also define a hashCode() method
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Array Declared Public, Final, and Static
cwe.description: The product declares an array public, final, and static, which is not sufficient to prevent the array's contents from being modified.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use public static nonfinal variables
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: finalize() Method Declared Public
cwe.description: The product violates secure coding principles for mobile code by declaring a finalize() method public.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Return Inside Finally Block
cwe.description: The code has a return statement inside a finally block, which will cause any thrown exception in the try block to be discarded.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not complete abruptly from a finally block
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not let checked exceptions escape from a finally block
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Empty Synchronized Block
cwe.description: The product contains an empty synchronized block.

cwe.name: Explicit Call to Finalize()
cwe.description: The product makes an explicit call to the finalize() method from outside the finalizer.

taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Assignment of a Fixed Address to a Pointer
cwe.description: The product sets a pointer to a specific address other than NULL or 0.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Converting a pointer to integer or integer to pointer

cwe.name: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer
cwe.description: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.

cwe.name: Call to Non-ubiquitous API
cwe.description: The product uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences.

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Do not use deprecated or obsolete classes or methods
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Maintain serialization compatibility during class evolution
taxonomyMappings.Taxonomy_Name: The CERT Oracle Secure Coding Standard for Java (2011)

cwe.name: Free of Memory not on the Heap
cwe.description: The product calls free() on a pointer to memory that was not allocated using associated heap allocation functions such as malloc(), calloc(), or realloc().

taxonomyMappings.Entry_Name: Properly pair allocation and deallocation functions

cwe.name: Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory
